item.title: (Course) CS50x - Harvard OpenCourseWare
item.description: #course_cs50 #moc Instructor: David J. Malan | CS50x 2024 About this course CS50 is Harvard University’s introductory course in computer science and programming, designed for both beginners and those with some experience.

item.title: (Course) Inferential Statistics - Coursera
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #moc Instructor: Mine Ã‡etinkaya-Rundel | Link to course About this course This course covers commonly used statistical inference methods for numerical and categorical data.

item.title: (Course) Reinforcement Learning - Google DeepMind
item.description: #course_google-deepmind-reinforcement-learning #moc Instructor: David Silver | Link to course | Website Recommended textbooks An Introduction to Reinforcement Learning, Sutton and Barto 1998 Around 400 pages, good for intuition Algorithms for Reinforcement Learning, Szepesvari 2010 Less than 100 pages, more for the maths behind it all Contents Part I: Elementary Reinforcement Learning [[1 RL Introduction to Reinforcement Learning]] [[2 RL Markov Decision Processes]] [[3 RL Planning by Dynamic Programming]] [[4 RL Model-Free Prediction]] [[5 RL Model-Free Control]] Part II: Reinforcement Learning in Practice [[6 RL Value Function Approximation]] [[7 RL Policy Gradient Methods]] [[8 RL Integrating Learning and Planning]] [[9 RL Exploration and Exploitation]] [[10 RL Case Study - RL in Games]]

item.title: (Textbook) Introduction to Statistical Learning (2nd edn)
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning #moc Authors: Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani | Website Table of contents Introduction [[1.1 An Overview of Statistical Learning]] [[1.

item.title: 01 DK Containers and their Advantages
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Advantages of Containers Containers A container is a portable computing environment, it contains everything needed (including dependencies, code, and configuration) to run a workflow or an application.

item.title: 02 DK The Docker Engine
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Docker is an open-source tool that allows us to create, run, and manage containers. Docker’s creation in 2013 caused containers (which already existed) to explode in popularity.

item.title: 03 DK Containers vs. Virtual Machines
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Containers and Virtual Machines Containers and VMs both enable you to run processes side-by-side on the same physical machine without interfering with each other.

item.title: 04 DK Running Docker Containers
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker This lesson focuses on starting, stopping, and looking at the output of containers. We’ll be using the following shell commands: Command Usage nano <file-name> Opens <file-name> in the nano text editor touch <file-name> Creates an empty file with the specified <file-name> echo "<text>" Print <text> to the console <command> >> <file> Push the output of <command> to the end of <file> <command> -y Automatically respond yes to all prompts from <command> Summary of covered commands: Command Usage docker run <image-name> Run a Docker image docker run -it <image-name> Run a Docker image and gain access to an interactive shell docker run -d <image-name> Run a Docker image in the background with no printed outputs docker ps List all running Docker containers docker stop <container-id> Stop a Docker container The Docker CLI The Docker command line interface sends instructions to the Docker daemon.

item.title: 05 DK Working with Docker containers
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Summary of covered commands: Command Usage docker run --name <container-name> <image-name> Run a Docker and give it a <container-name> docker ps -f "name=<container-name>" Filter list of running container based on name docker logs <container-name> See logs for container docker logs -f <container-name> Follow logs live for container docker container rm <container-id> Completely remove a Docker container Listing containers docker ps is useful when wor;’//king with a handful of containers, but quickly becomes difficult to use when you have more.

item.title: 06 DK Managing Local Docker Images
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker All images used to create containers so far have been provided to us. In reality, we will be working with containers we created ourselves, or have downloaded from the community.

item.title: 07 DK Distributing Docker Images
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Summary of covered commands: Command Usage docker pull <private-registry-url>/<image-name>:<ver> Pull an image from a private registry docker tag <image-name>:<ver> <private-registry-url>/<image-name>:<ver> Rename an image for pushing to a private registry docker image push <image-name> Push an image to a registry docker login <private-registry-url> Authenticate with a private registry docker save -o <file-name>.

item.title: 08 DK Create your own Docker Images
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Dockerfiles The recipe for each image is contained in a Dockerfile. The first line in any Dockerfile is always a FROM command.

item.title: 09 DK Managing Files in your Image
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker We’ve seen how to create a Docker image using another image as a starting point, as well as how to run arbitrary shell commands upon build.

item.title: 1 Central Limit Theorem and Sampling Distributions
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Introduction We start this course off with an example study by Pew Research which quotes: 41% of the public believe that young adults, rather than middle-aged or older adults, are having the toughest time in our economy.

item.title: 1 D3 Overview
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 D3 stands for Data-Driven Documents and has risen to popularity due to various reasons: D3 has revolutionised the way that data visualisation is built natively on the web.

item.title: 1 Introduction - Mathematical Thinking
item.description: #course_coursera-intro-maths-thinking Introductory lecture Mathematical thinking is a powerful way of thinking that has been developed over 3,000 years.

item.title: 1 RL Introduction to Reinforcement Learning
item.description: #course_google-deepmind-reinforcement-learning #reinforcement-learning Slide link About reinforcement learning ![[Pasted image 20230816152354.png]] Reinforcement learning (RL) sits at the intersection of many different fields of science.

item.title: 1 TS Introduction
item.description: #course_codecademy-typescript #typescript Introduction JavaScript was designed to be flexible and easy to use for small applications. However, this makes the language less ideal for building larger applications.

item.title: 1.1 An Overview of Statistical Learning
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning Statistical learning refers to a set of tools for understanding data. Can be [[2.1.4 Supervised Versus Unsupervised Learning#^31a009|supervised]] (predicting/estimating an output using inputs) or [[2.

item.title: 1.2 Notation and Simple Matrix Algebra
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning General notation $n$ denotes the number of distinct data points available $p$ denotes the number of variables that are available for use Variable names are referred to with coloured monospace font Feature space

item.title: 10 DK Choosing a Start Command for your Image
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker The images we’ve created so far do not do anything upon running them as containers. In this lesson we’ll talk about having the image execute commands once it starts as a container.

item.title: 11 DK Introduction to Docker Caching
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Building Docker images can take a significant amount of time, but building them a second time can be much faster.

item.title: 12 DK Changing Users and Working Directory
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker FROM, COPY, RUN instructions only affect the file system of the image, and do not modify each other.

item.title: 13 DK Variables in Dockerfiles
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Using variables inside our Dockerfiles makes them easier to maintain and update as well as being less verbose.

item.title: 14 DK Creating secure Docker images
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker Docker containers don’t make everything automatically secure. In this lesson we’ll look at the security measures Docker provides us inherently, as well as what we can do to make them more secure.

item.title: 15 DK Next steps
item.description: #course_datacamp-docker #docker There are more, albeit less used Docker commands to learn. ENTRYPOINT, HEALTHCHECK, EXPOSE We can also learn how to create a new image from scratch, or how to create multi-stage builds allowing you to create images built off multiple Docker images at once.

item.title: 2 Confidence Intervals
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Introduction A plausible range of values for the population parameter is called a confidence interval. Using only a sample statistic to estimate a population parameter is like fishing in a murky lake with a spear.

item.title: 2 D3 Selection
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 D3 works by ‘injecting’ data visualisations onto an object’s [[Document Object Model]], and associates data with a set of DOM elements.

item.title: 2 RL Markov Decision Processes
item.description: #course_google-deepmind-reinforcement-learning #reinforcement-learning Slide link Markov processes Markov decision processes (MDPs) formally describe an environment for machine learning We’ll start with the nice case where the environment is fully observable.

item.title: 2 TS Type Inferences
item.description: #course_codecademy-typescript #typescript JavaScript lets us assign any value to any variable which makes it flexible and easy to use in the first instance.

item.title: 2.1 Names and Values - Introduction
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r It is important to understand the distinction between an object and its name in R. This will help you:

item.title: 2.1 What is Statistical Learning
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning For any dataset, we assume there’s a relationship between $Y$ and $X = (X_1, X_2, \dots, X_p)$ which can be represented in the general form: $$Y = f(x) + psilon$$ Where $f$ is a fixed but unknown function of $X_1, \dots, X_p$, and $psilon$ is a random error term (independent of $X$ and mean 0).

item.title: 2.1.1 Why Estimate f
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning Estimating $f$ can be useful for both prediction (predicting the response for future observations - prediction accuracy is paramount here) and inference (better understanding the relationship between the inputs and the output - interpretability is the priority).

item.title: 2.1.2 How Do We Estimate f
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning Techniques for estimating $f$ can be characterised as either parametric or non-parametric. Parametric techniques require that a functional form be assumed for the data, which provides a set of parameters that one needs to estimate using the data.

item.title: 2.1.3 The Trade-Off Between Prediction Accuracy and Model Interpretability
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning Why would we use a more restrictive method instead of a flexible approach? There is often a trade-off between how restrictive a model is and how interpretable it is.

item.title: 2.1.4 Supervised Versus Unsupervised Learning
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning Supervised learning refers to the problem set where for each observation of the predictor measurements ($x_i$, $i=1,\dots,n$) there is an associated response measurement ($y_i$).

item.title: 2.1.5 Regression Versus Classification Problems
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning Variables are either quantitative (numerical) or qualitative (categorical). We refer to problems with a quantitative response as regression problems; whereas those with qualitative responses are referred to as classification problems.

item.title: 2.2 Assessing Model Accuracy
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning There is no free lunch in statistics. No one method dominates all others over all possible datasets.

item.title: 2.2 Binding Basics
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r 1 x <- c(1, 2, 3) It’s easy to read this as ‘create an object named “x”, containing the values 1, 2, 3’, but this is an oversimplification and a misrepresentation of what occurs in the back end.

item.title: 2.2.1 Measuring the Quality of Fit (Regression)
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning We need to quantify the extent to which the predicted response value for a given observation is close to the true response value for that observation.

item.title: 2.2.2 The Bias-Variance Trade-Off
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning It is possible to show that the expected test MSE (for a given value $x_0$) can be decomposed into the sum of the variance of $\hat{f}(x_0)$, the squared bias of $\hat{f}(x_0)$ and the variance of the irreducible error terms $psilon$.

item.title: 2.2.3 Measuring the Quality of Fit (Classification)
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning The concepts discussed so far (like the bias-variance trade-off) apply to both regression and classification problems, albeit with some differences.

item.title: 2.2.3.1 The Bayes Classifier
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning #bayes-classifier The Bayes Classifier minimises the test error rate by assigning each observation to the most likely class, given its predictor values.

item.title: 2.2.3.2 K-Nearest Neighbours
item.description: #textbook_intro-to-statistical-learning #k-nearest-neighbours Many methods try to estimate the conditional distribution of Y given X, and then classify an observation to the class with the highest estimated probability.

item.title: 2.3 Copy-on-modify
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r The following code creates a vector and binds x and y names to that object. It then modifies y.

item.title: 2.4 Object Size
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r You can find how much memory an object takes with lobstr::obj_size(). Elements of lists are just references to values to the following list won’t be as large as you might think.

item.title: 2.5 Modify-in-Place
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r There are some exceptions to when R makes a copy of an object if it gets modified: Objects with a single name binding get a special performance optimisation Environments (a special type of object) are always modified in place 2.

item.title: 2.6 Unbinding and the Garbage Collector
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r When we do this: 1 2 3 x <- 1:3 x <- 2:4 rm(x) We’re binding 1:3 to x, then binding 2:4 to x instead, then removing that binding.

item.title: 3 D3 Data-Element Relationship
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 With elements [[2 D3 Selection|selected]], we can now associate data per element. You do this with .data() which takes an array of any type and binds its elements to the selected objects returned by .

item.title: 3 Hypothesis Testing
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Another Introduction to Inference We’ll start with an example of a first-principles hypothesis test that the last course ended on.

item.title: 3 Linear Regression
item.description: #regression Linear regression is a very simple supervised learning method for predicting a quantitative response. It serves as a good jumping-off point for newer approaches since many more complex statistical learning approaches can be seen as generalisations or extensions of linear regression.

item.title: 3 RL Planning by Dynamic Programming
item.description: #course_google-deepmind-reinforcement-learning #reinforcement-learning Slide link Introduction Dynamic programming is one of the ways in in which we solve Markov Decision Processes.

item.title: 3 TS Type Shapes
item.description: #course_codecademy-typescript #typescript Since TS knows what type our objects are, it also knows what shape they take. The shape of an object describes (amongst other things) what methods and properties it may contain.

item.title: 3.1 Simple Linear Regression
item.description: #simple-linear-regression #regression Straightforward approach for predicting a quantitative response $Y$ on the basis of a single predictor variable $X$. It assumes there is a linear relationship between X and Y at the population level, ie.

item.title: 3.1 Vectors - Introduction
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r Vectors are the most important family of data types in base R. This chapter will go through how all the types fit together as a whole.

item.title: 3.2 Atomic Vectors
item.description: #textbook_advanced-r #r The four primary types of atomic vectors are: Logical Integer Double Character There are two rarer types, complex (as in complex numbers) and raw (binary data).

item.title: 3.2 Multiple Linear Regression
item.description: #multiple-linear-regression #regression When modelling something that is influenced by multiple predictors, fitting a separate simple linear regression model for each predictor is not sufficient as each model ignores the other predictors.

item.title: 3.3 Attributes
item.description: Matrices, arrays, factors, and date-times are all extensions of atomic vectors. We build these constructs by adding attributes on top of atomic vectors.

item.title: 3.3 Other Considerations in the Regression Model
item.description: $$ y_i = eta_0 + eta_1 x_i + psilon_i = egin{cases} eta_0 + eta_1 + psilon_i & ext{if } i ext{th person owns a house} eta_0 + psilon_i & ext{if } i ext{th person does not.

item.title: 3.4 S3 Atomic Vectors
item.description: Another important attribute that vectors can have (in addition to names and dim) is class. If a vector has a class attribute then it becomes an S3 object; which in turn means that it will behave differently when passed through a generic function.

item.title: 4 D3 The d Parameter
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 After we’ve [[2 D3 Selection|selected]] our elements and [[3 D3 Data-Element Relationship|bound]] our dataset to them, we’ll need to find a way to properly display that data in those elements.

item.title: 4 RL Model-Free Prediction
item.description: #course_google-deepmind-reinforcement-learning #reinforcement-learning Slide link Model-free prediction: Take an environment that can be represented as a MDP, but no one gives us the information on this (unlike with dynamic programming).

item.title: 4 Statistical Significance
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Inference for Other Estimators The methods we’ve been learning can be applied to other estimators that have nearly-normal sampling distributions, which are listed here:

item.title: 4 TS Variable Type Annotations
item.description: #course_codecademy-typescript #typescript We can assert the type of a variable upon initialisation by using a type annotation. We do this with the : symbol.

item.title: 5 D3 Enter, Exit and Update
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 Enter/Update/Exit When you seeÂ selectAll()Â followed byÂ .data()Â we are: Selecting all matching elements For each element that exists, we bind an item from the data array to it .

item.title: 5 t-distribution and Comparing Two Means
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Inference for Numerical Variables We’ll build upon the tools we’ve used to perform inference on numerical variables in this unit.

item.title: 6 ANOVA and Bootstrapping
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Comparing more than two means The data we’ll consider here comes from the General Social Survey. We’re interested in the average vocabulary score split by self-identified social class:

item.title: 6 D3 Chaining and Returning
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 Conventional chaining styling for D3 will use a single-indented line to indicate when the selection is changing, and a double-indented line for operations on the current selection, e.

item.title: 7 D3 Interactivity with Events
item.description: #course_codecademy-d3 #d3 Another powerful aspect of D3 is that it has access to [[Document Object Model|DOM]] events. The .on() method takes the event as a string and a function to run upon that event and binds this function to the elements in the selection.

item.title: 7 Inference for Proportions
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Introduction This week we discuss categorical variables where the metric of interest is a proportion (e.g. proportion of elderly patients taking antihypertensive medications that experience falls).

item.title: 8 Simulation based inference for proportions and chi-square testing
item.description: #course_coursera-inferential-stats #statistics Small sample proportions If the success-failure â‰¥ 10 rule (i.e. the Sample Size/Skew condition) is not satisfied, then the sampling distribution for your given scenario will not adhere to the CLT, reducing the effectiveness of CLT-based methods.

item.title: ASCII
item.description: #course_cs50 How do we represent language in a way that can be understood by computers? We can assign numbers to each letter.

item.title: Binary
item.description: #course_cs50 base-2 Our everyday number system is a decimal-based (i.e. base-10) one. Take the number 123 for example, we can think of this as 1 in the 100s slot, 2 in the 10s slot, 3 in the 1s slot; adding them we get 123 Generalising this, each of those slots is 10 to the power of something: $100 = 10^2, 10 = 10^1, 1 = 10^0$ If we wanted to switch to a binary system, i.

item.title: Document Object Model
item.description: TheÂ Document Object ModelÂ (DOM) is the data representation of the objects that comprise the structure and content of a document on the web.

item.title: Farrington Flexible Aberration Detection
item.description: #excess-mortality #regression #farrington-flexible A quasi-Poisson regression-based aberration detection algorithm Useful links R surveillance function definition for farringtonFlexible() Official documentation Comparison of statistical algorithms for daily syndromic surveillance aberration detection, Noufaily et al.

item.title: plida-training
item.description: ![[A1_Introduction to PLIDA.pdf]]

item.title: Pseudocode
item.description: #course_cs50 Used to describe a code algorithm succinctly and accurately. We can break up the example pseudocode below into functions (verbs), control flow (if-else), boolean expressions, and loops.

item.title: README
item.description: A second ðŸ§ #moc TODO: This vault has been published using Quartz to https://wongd-hub.github.io/obsidian-quartz. However there are some issues: Using rsync to copy files over from one repo to another upon push to this repo.

item.title: RGB
item.description: #course_cs50 This is one of the ways we can represent colours as a sequence of numbers. We can generate every colour of the rainbow by varying the amount of Red, Green, and Blue being displayed.

item.title: Unicode
item.description: #course_cs50 Unicode is a superset of ASCII as we realised we need more bits to represent languages, emojis, etc. Unicode’s mission is to represent and preserve all human language both past, present, and future.

item.title: What is Computer Science?
item.description: #course_cs50 Study of information Solving problems with certain ideas and techniques Problem solving is a goal we’ll approach with computational thinking Problem solving flowchart LR Input Empty["
